questions.question: Which of the following is true about polyarteritis nodosa?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) 30% is associated with Hepatitis B Explanation: 30% of polyarteritis nodosa is associated with Hepatitis B. Polyarteritis Nodosa: A multisystem, necrotizing vasculitis of small- and medium-sized muscular arteries. (Option A) Characteristically involves renal and visceral arteries. Kidneys: Arteritis without glomerulonephritis; glomerulosclerosis may be seen in hypertensive patients. Polyarteritis nodosa-like vasculitis may be seen in 30% of patients with hepatitis B , with circulating immune complexes composed of hepatitis B antigen and immunoglobulin. Pathology and Pathogenesis: Vascular lesion: Necrotizing inflammation of small- and medium-sized arteries. Lesions are segmental, involving bifurcations and branches of arteries. In acute stages: Polymorphonuclear neutrophils infiltrate vessel walls and perivascular areas, causing intimal proliferation and degeneration. In subacute and chronic stages: Mononuclear cells infiltrate, leading to fibrinoid necrosis, lumen compromise, thrombosis, infarction, and hemorrhage. Aneurysmal dilations up to 1 cm in size are characteristic. Clinical Manifestations: Nonspecific symptoms: Fever, weight loss, malaise, weakness, headache, abdominal pain, myalgias. Renal involvement: Hypertension, renal insufficiency, hemorrhage due to microaneurysms. Laboratory findings: Leukocytosis with neutrophil predominance (eosinophilia is rare). Anemia of chronic disease. Elevated ESR and CRP. Hypergammaglobulinemia may be present. (Option B) Hepatitis B and C screening is essential. ANCA is rarely present. (Option C) Diagnosis: Based on biopsy of involved organs (e.g., nodular skin lesions, painful testes, nerve/muscle) for vasculitis findings. Treatment: Prednisone and cyclophosphamide significantly improve survival. In patients with hepatitis B or C, antiviral therapy should be included along with glucocorticoids and plasma exchange. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2810,2811 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S089684110090502X

questions.question: A patient presents with flaccid bullous lesions as shown in the image below involving the entire trunk and oral cavity. Acantholytic cells are seen on Tzank smear. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Pemphigus vulgaris Explanation: As the patient is presenting with flaccid bullous lesions involving the entire trunk and oral cavity, along with the presence of acantholytic cells on Tzanck smear, the most probable diagnosis would be Pemphigus vulgaris. However, a definitive diagnosis would require additional clinical evaluation, including a biopsy and direct immunofluorescence testing. Pemphigus vulgaris (PV): PV is the most common chronic autoimmune blistering disease caused by antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins. They are characterized by the presence of flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid present on normal skin or an erythematous base. The blisters rupture producing painful erosion. Mucosal involvement is a very important and one of the distinguishing features of PV. Histopathology: Intraepidermal cleavage with acantholysis (detached keratinocytes) primarily localized to the suprabasal region Separation of basal keratinocytes along the basement membrane zone, resulting in an appearance that resembles a "row of tombstones" The target antigens for PV are most commonly Desmoglein 3 and sometimes Desmoglein 1. questions.question: A patient presented with sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx, nodular lesions with cavitations of the lung, and renal failure. Which of the following is the most useful investigation in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Test for ANCA Explanation: The clinical scenario of sinusitis, ulcerative lesions on the nasopharynx (upper respiratory tract), nodular lesions with cavitation in the lungs (lower respiratory tract), and renal failure strongly suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis . The most useful investigation in this case is a test for ANCA. Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (GPA): GPA is a vasculitic disorder characterized by granulomatous inflammation of the upper and lower respiratory tracts , small vessel vasculitis, and pauci-immune glomerulonephritis. Pathology and Pathogenesis: Hallmarks: Necrotizing vasculitis and granuloma formation in affected organs. Organs involved: Lungs: Nodular cavitary infiltrates ; necrotizing granulomatous vasculitis. Kidneys: Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis with minimal immune complex deposition. Upper airway: Granulomatous inflammation , necrosis, nasal septal perforation, and saddle nose deformity. Immune imbalance: Predominantly Th1-mediated cytokine response with elevated IFN- γ , TNF- α , and IL-12. Clinical Features: Respiratory tract: Paranasal sinus pain , nasal discharge (purulent/bloody), subglottic stenosis, cough, hemoptysis, and dyspnea. Renal: Proteinuria, hematuria, red blood cell casts, and progressive renal failure. Skin: Palpable purpura, ulcers, or nodules with vasculitis. Ocular: Conjunctivitis, episcleritis, retro-orbital masses, and proptosis. Neurological: Mononeuritis multiplex, cranial neuritis, or cerebral vasculitis. Systemic symptoms: Malaise, fever, weight loss, arthralgia, and fatigue. Diagnosis: Biopsy: Lung biopsy: High diagnostic yield, showing granulomatous vasculitis. Renal biopsy: Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis. Serology: Antiproteinase-3 ANCA positivity (~90%). Treatment: Induction Therapy: Glucocorticoids, cyclophosphamide or rituximab Maintenance Therapy: Azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil or methotrexate Biopsy to show granuloma (Option B) : While granulomas may be seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), their absence does not exclude the diagnosis. Biopsy findings are supportive but not definitive, and testing for ANCA is less invasive and provides earlier diagnostic information. AFB staining of sputum (Option C) is primarily used for diagnosing tuberculosis, which does not match the clinical presentation of combined upper and lower respiratory tract involvement with renal failure seen in GPA. BAL (Bronchoalveolar Lavage) (Option D) can help evaluate lung involvement and detect inflammatory cells but is not specific for GPA. ANCA testing is more specific and less invasive for confirming the diagnosis in this case. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page 2806-2809

questions.question: A patient with giant cell arteritis presented with headache, jaw claudication, polymyalgia rheumatica, and mononeuritis multiplex. What should be the first-line treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Steroids Explanation: The symptoms suggest the diagnosis of Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA), for which the first line of treatment is administering steroids . Giant Cell Arteritis (GCA): GCA is an inflammatory condition of medium and large-sized arteries Earlier called temporal arteritis due to temporal artery involvement It's a systemic vasculitis affecting carotid artery branches and the aorta and its major branches It occurs almost exclusively in people over 50 years Shows strong female predominance Genetic associations: HLA-DR4 and HLA-DRB1*04 variants Strong association with polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR): 40-50% of GCA patients have PMR 10-20% of PMR patients later develop GCA Clinical Manifestations: Common Symptoms: Fever Headaches Malaise and fatigue Anorexia and weight loss Sweats Arthralgias Scalp pain Jaw claudication Complications: Ischemic optic neuropathy leading to blindness Strokes Scalp/tongue infarction Large vessel complications (in up to 1/3rd of patients): Subclavian artery stenosis Aortic aneurysms (thoracic > abdominal) Risk of aortic rupture or dissection Treatment Protocol: Initial Management: Prednisone 40-60 mg/day for 1 month IV methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for 3 days if ocular symptoms Aspirin (Option D) 81 mg daily to reduce cranial ischemic complications Additional Therapies: Tocilizumab (anti-IL-6) FDA approved (Option B) Given as 162 mg SC weekly/biweekly with steroids Methotrexate as alternative steroid-sparing agent Monitoring: Treatment typically needed for ≥ 2 years ESR/CRP is useful for monitoring 60-85% have symptom recurrence during tapering Watch for glucocorticoid toxicity (35-65% of patients) Abatacept (Option A) can be used to treat giant cell arteritis along with prednisolone to reduce the risk of relapse. However, it is not the first-line treatment. Aspirin (Option D) is not the first-line treatment for giant cell arteritis and is only prescribed for cases with high ischemic risks. Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Volume I, Page: 2811, 2812.

questions.question: A woman presents with numbness of her fingertips. On examination, her face is tightened. The antinuclear antibody(ANA) is found to be positive and immunofluorescence shows the nucleolar pattern. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Systemic sclerosis Explanation: Numbness in fingertips and tightened face with ANA finding positive and nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence suggest systemic sclerosis. Dermal Manifestations of Systemic Sclerosis (SSc): Bilateral Symmetrical Skin Thickening : Begins distally in the fingers and progresses proximally. Skin Pigmentation Changes : Early diffuse tanning without sun exposure. Hypopigmentation with a "salt-and-pepper" appearance on the scalp, upper back, and chest is common in dark-skinned individuals. Sclerosis of Skin and Loss of Appendages : Leads to hair loss, reduced sweating, xerosis, and itching. Disappearance of transverse finger creases and fixed flexion contractures causing muscle atrophy. Fixed Contractures : Affects wrists, elbows, and knees due to skin and tendon fibrosis. Neck Skin Ridges : Firm adherence to platysma muscle limits neck extension. Facial Changes ("Mauskopf") : Taut, shiny skin with loss of wrinkles and reduced mobility. Thinned lips, prominent perioral radial furrows, and microstomia. Pinched, beak-like nose. Telangiectasia : Dilated capillaries on face, hands, lips, and oral mucosa; correlated with microvascular disease severity. Skin Ulcerations : Chronic ulcers on fingertips, PIP joints, and bony prominences heal slowly and may become infected. Fingertip ischemia leaves fixed digital "pits." Acro-Osteolysis: Resorption of terminal phalanges due to ischemia. Calcinosis Cutis : Dystrophic calcifications in the skin and soft tissues, commonly in patients with anti-centromere antibody–positive lcSSc. Calcific deposits vary in size and may ulcerate, causing pain, infections, or nerve compression. Immunofluorescence: The nucleolar pattern in immunofluorescence detecting Th/To autoantibodies. Incorrect Options: Sjögren's Syndrome (Option B) is an autoimmune disorder primarily affecting moisture-producing glands, leading to dry mouth and eyes, gritty eye sensation, fatigue, joint pain, etc. Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (Option C) is a multisystem autoimmune disease that can affect many organs. Common manifestations include a malar (butterfly) rash, joint pain, kidney problems, and blood abnormalities. While SLE may cause numbness or tingling due to nerve involvement, its ANA pattern is typically homogeneous or speckled, not nucleolar. Rheumatoid arthritis (Option D) primarily affects the joints, causing inflammation, pain, and stiffness. It does not typically involve numbness of the fingertips or the tightening of the face seen in systemic sclerosis. Additionally, the nucleolar pattern on ANA immunofluorescence testing is not associated with rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.question: A 36-year-old woman presented with claudication in the forearm, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain. Femoral pulses were weak. Fundus examination revealed retinal haemorrhages. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Takayasu arteritis Explanation: The clinical scenario of forearm claudication, transient loss of vision, and abdominal pain with weak femoral pulses point to the diagnosis of Takayasu arteritis. Takayasu Arteritis ("Pulseless disease"): General features: Predominantly affects young females (<20 years) Vascular Involvement: A leading cause of renal artery stenosis in India Most commonly affects the left subclavian artery Characteristic ostial narrowing vs. diffuse involvement in atherosclerosis Clinical Features: a) Early Phase (Pre-pulseless): Systemic symptoms: fever, malaise, night sweats Arthralgias, anorexia, weight loss b) Vascular Phase: Arm claudication Unequal blood pressure between arms Pulseless disease (difficult to appreciate radial artery) Hypertension (32-93%) Differential Diagnosis: Young female with renal artery stenosis: India: Think Takayasu arteritis USA: Think fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) Arm claudication: Rule out neurogenic claudication (cervical disc disease) Investigations: ESR/CRP elevation Mild anaemia Elevated immunoglobulins Investigation of choice: MR angiography (MRA) Complete imaging of the aorta and major branches is needed Management: First Line: Steroids (40-60mg prednisone/day) Second Line: Methotrexate ( up to 25mg/week) for steroid-refractory cases Important Points for Differential Blood Pressure: Normal difference between arm-leg BP: <20 mmHg Conditions with unequal arm BPs: Takayasu arteritis Supravalvular aortic stenosis with Coanda effect Preductal coarctation of aorta Major complications: Heart failure, stroke, MI, aneurysm rupture, renal failure. Incorrect Options: Polyarteritis nodosa (Option A) presents non-specific symptoms like weakness, malaise, headache, abdominal pain, and myalgia. These symptoms do not align with the given scenario. Thromboangitis obliterans (Option B) or Buerger disease affects the small to medium arteries and veins and presents with ischemic signs and symptoms in the regions of the distal arteries of the upper and lower limbs. In this condition, claudication is seen in the arch of the foot and calf and is also called the Raynauds phenomenon. Microscopic polyangiitis (Option D) is a rare autoimmune disease where there is small vessel necrotizing vasculitis that manifests as systemic symptoms involving the kidneys (rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis), lungs (diffuse alveolar haemorrhage, chronic interstitial fibrosis), skin (palpable purpura, urticaria, nodules, etc), GIT (bleeding), and CNS (peripheral neuropathy). Reference: Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page: 2810, 2813. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430858/ https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK531484/

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is not associated with Iritis ?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Rheumatoid arthritis Explanation: Iritis, also known as anterior uveitis, is inflammation of the iris and ciliary body. It can occur as a result of various underlying conditions. Among the options given, Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) is not typically associated with iritis . But conjunctiva and sclera are usually involved. Systemic Associations and Masquerades of Anterior Uveitis: Infectious Causes : Herpes Infections: Varicella Zoster, Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) Tuberculosis (TB) Syphilis Leprosy Non-Infectious Causes : With Systemic Association : Sarcoidosis Behçet's Disease (Option B) HLA-B27 Associated Arthritis Inflammatory Bowel Disease: Ulcerative Colitis (UC) (Option C) > Crohn's Disease SLE (Option A) Without Systemic Association : Drug-Induced: Pilocarpine, prostaglandin analogues Masquerade Syndromes : Definition : Conditions that mimic the symptoms of anterior uveitis but are not primarily inflammatory in nature. Neoplastic Masquerades : Lymphomas Anterior Segment Melanoma Retinoblastoma Metastasis Non-Neoplastic Masquerades : Intraocular Foreign Body Old Retinal Detachment Pigment Dispersion Syndrome Coats' Disease Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic inflammatory disorder involving >2 organs. Iritis is one of the ocular manifestations of sarcoidosis. Behcet's disease is a rare autoimmune condition characterized by recurrent oral and genital ulcers, skin lesions, and uveitis. Uveitis, including iritis, is a well-known ocular manifestation of Behcet's disease. Ulcerative colitis is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that primarily affects the colon and rectum. While its primary manifestations are related to the gastrointestinal system, extraintestinal manifestations can occur, including ocular involvement. Uveitis, including iritis, can occur in patients with ulcerative colitis. Reference: Kanski’s Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 424

questions.question: A patient presented with uveitis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis. Which of the following is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) HLA-B27 Explanation: The combination of uveitis, enthesitis, and sacroiliitis is characteristic of ankylosing spondylitis (AS) and other spondyloarthropathies, which are strongly associated with HLA-B27. Ankylosing Spondylitis Clinical Features General Features Spine and Joint involvement Extra-articular manifestations Inflammatory back pain : Gradual onset, worse with inactivity, improves with movement and is often associated with early morning stiffness. Fatigue : A common and significant symptom. Postural changes : Loss of lumbar lordosis, increased thoracic kyphosis, and forward stooping of the neck. Enthesitis : Inflammation at tendon or ligament attachment sites, often mistaken for fibromyalgia. Peripheral joint involvement : Affects large joints like hips, knees , and shoulders and is usually asymmetrical. Sacroiliac joint involvement : B/L and asymmetrical; pain may radiate to the buttocks or posterior thighs. Reduced spinal mobility: Limited movement in the lumbar region due to inflammation and pain, often accompanied by muscle spasms. Anterior uveitis: Most common extra articular manifestation. Presents with sudden unilateral eye pain, redness, and light sensitivity, often preceding joint symptoms. Anaemia, prostatitis, inflammatory bowel disease, aortic valve disease, and very rare cases of amyloidosis or upper lobe pulmonary fibrosis Osteoporosis : This can lead to vertebral fractures, especially with spinal fusion. Investigations of Ankylosing Spondylitis Tests X-rays MRI HLA-B27: The presence of the HLA-B27 gene is a strong indicator of AS. The prevalence of AS in the general population is less than 0.5%. Inflammatory Markers : Elevated ESR and CRP levels may indicate active disease. Faecal Calprotectin : Helps screen for associated inflammatory bowel disease. Show characteristic changes in sacroiliac joints , such as: Blurred cortical margins Erosions and sclerosis "Pseudowidening" of joint space (early stages) Joint space narrowing and fusion (later stages) Bamboo spine - Vertebral body fusion by syndesmophytes Dagger sign - Calcification appears as a single radiodense line vertically running down the spine on frontal radiographs. Investigation of choice – more sensitive than X-rays for detecting early inflammatory changes. Can reveal bone marrow oedema, enthesitis, synovitis, and erosions. questions.question: A 54-year-old female patient visits you with symptoms of finger swelling, heartburn, and occasional joint pain. During the examination, her hands appeared shiny, tight, and thickened with non-pitting oedema. Additionally, she has interstitial lung disease and tests positive for ANA antibodies, topoisomerase I antibodies, and anti-RNA polymerase III antibodies. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis Explanation: Diffuse Scleroderma Skin thickening over large body areas (fingers, hands, arms, anterior trunk, legs, and face). Significant risk of organ damage (GI tract, kidneys, lungs, heart). Associated with skin dryness, itching, and musculoskeletal pain. Life-threatening when lungs or heart are severely involved. Acute, severe high blood pressure can lead to kidney damage. Dermal Manifestations of Systemic Sclerosis (SSc) Bilateral Symmetrical Skin Thickening : Begins distally in the fingers and progresses proximally. Skin Pigmentation Changes : Early diffuse tanning without sun exposure. Hypopigmentation with a "salt-and-pepper" appearance on the scalp, upper back, and chest is common in dark-skinned individuals. Sclerosis of Skin and Loss of Appendages : Leads to hair loss, reduced sweating, xerosis, and itching. Disappearance of transverse finger creases and fixed flexion contractures causing muscle atrophy. Fixed Contractures : Affects wrists, elbows, and knees due to skin and tendon fibrosis. Neck Skin Ridges : Firm adherence to platysma muscle limits neck extension. Facial Changes ("Mauskopf") : Taut, shiny skin with loss of wrinkles and reduced mobility. Thinned lips, prominent perioral radial furrows, and microstomia. Pinched, beak-like nose. Telangiectasia : Dilated capillaries on face, hands, lips, and oral mucosa; correlated with microvascular disease severity. Skin Ulcerations : Chronic ulcers on fingertips, PIP joints, and bony prominences heal slowly and may become infected. Fingertip ischemia leaves fixed digital "pits." Acro-Osteolysis: Resorption of terminal phalanges due to ischemia. Calcinosis Cutis : Dystrophic calcifications in the skin and soft tissues, commonly in patients with anti-centromere antibody–positive lcSSc. Calcific deposits vary in size and may ulcerate, causing pain, infections, or nerve compression. Incorrect Options: Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (Option A) is positive for anti-centromere antibody or ACA. Raynaud’s phenomenon (Option C) is one of the characteristic presentations of diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis. Some body parts, like the fingers and nose, feel numb and cool in response to cold temperatures or stress. Peutz-jeghers syndrome (Option D) is an inherited condition that increases the risk of hamartomatous polyps in the GIT and cancers in the GIT and that of the breast, testicles, and ovaries. Since there are no polyps, PJS is unlikely to be the diagnosis.

questions.question: A 45-year-old woman complains of dryness in her mouth and eyes and has positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies. The image below shows a positive test result with a score of less than 5 mm in 5 minutes without anaesthesia. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Sjogren Syndrome Explanation: The clinical features of dry eyes and mouth with a Schirmer’s test ≤ 5 mm/5 min and positive anti-Ro and anti-La antibodies suggest the diagnosis of Sjogren syndrome. Sjogren syndrome Pathogenesis: Sjogren Syndrome is an autoimmune disorder primarily affecting the exocrine glands. The pathogenesis involves lymphocytic infiltration (mainly T and B cells) into exocrine glands, especially the salivary and lacrimal glands. A complex interaction of genetic predisposition, environmental factors, and abnormal immune response triggers this infiltration. B-cell hyperactivity: Characterized by hypergammaglobulinemia and autoantibody production (e.g., anti-Ro/SSA and anti-La/SSB). Epithelial cell role: Exocrine gland epithelial cells may express autoantigens (Ro, La), produce pro-inflammatory cytokines, and express Toll-like receptors, facilitating immune activation I . Genetic predisposition: Certain HLA alleles (e.g., HLA-DQA1*0501) and immune-regulatory genes (IRF5, STAT4) increase susceptibility. Clinical Features: The hallmark symptoms are xerostomia (dry mouth) and keratoconjunctivitis sicca (dry eyes). questions.question: A 65-year-old man is experiencing chronic pain in his hands, knees, and hips, with increased pain in the hands during writing or typing. Additionally, he has morning stiffness in his joints that lasts for about 30 minutes. On examination, Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes are visible in the hands, and an X-ray of the knee shows narrowed joint space with osteophytes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Osteoarthritis Explanation: The clinical manifestations in the given scenario and the presence of Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes point to the diagnosis of osteoarthritis . Joint involvement in different types of arthritis: Characteristic Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) (Option C) Osteoarthritis (OA) (Option B) Psoriatic Arthritis Gout Reactive Arthritis Joint Involvement Pattern Symmetrical involvement of small joints (MCP, PIP) Asymmetrical involvement, especially DIP joints Asymmetrical involvement, often DIP joints Typically involves a single joint (e.g., big toe) Asymmetrical involvement, often larger joints Morning Stiffness Lasts over 1 hour Resolves within 30 minutes Varies, often significant Rarely significant Variable often follows infection Key Symptoms Swelling, tenderness, deformities (e.g., ulnar deviation) Pain and stiffness with use Dactylitis, nail changes Sudden, severe pain and swelling Joint pain following an infection Affected Joints MCP, PIP, wrists, knees Knees, hips, hands (DIP, PIP) MCP, PIP, and can include spine and tendons Typically big toe (1st MTP joint) Larger joints (e.g., knees, ankles) Radiographic Findings Soft tissue swelling, joint space narrowing Osteophytes, joint space narrowing Erosions, possible nail changes Erosions and tophi possible Similar to RA but typically larger joints Osteoporosis (Option A) is a condition where there is a reduction in bone mineral density and mass or a change in the quality and structure of bone. questions.question: A 52-year-old woman presented with changes in the hand as shown below. There is decreased motion in the small joints and loss of wrinkle lines on the facial skin. Her chest radiograph showed prominent bilateral lower lobe infiltrates. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.question: After confirming a diagnosis of gout, which of the following drugs is a purine analog that would be most appropriate for management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Allopurinol Explanation: Allopurinol is the first-line choice for gout management. It is a purine analog that acts as a xanthine oxidase inhibitor, effectively reducing uric acid production. The drug works through dual mechanisms : direct inhibition of xanthine oxidase and competition with phosphoribosylpyrophosphate in the salvage pathway. Allopurinol: Allopurinol is the first-line treatment for the prevention of gouty arthritis, particularly in patients who are overproducers of uric acid. The initial dose is typically 100 mg daily, with a target urate level of <5-6 mg/dL and can be titrated up to 800 mg as needed. In patients with renal impairment, dose adjustments are essential. Adverse effects : Stevens-Johnson syndrome Toxic epidermal necrolysis Acute gout flare-up, which may occur due to rapid urate level reduction To prevent flare-ups, anti-inflammatory therapy should be continued until the patient is normouricemic and has not had an attack for 3-6 months. Capecitabine (Option B) is a pyrimidine analog used in breast cancer treatment. This medication has no role in gout management and does not affect uric acid metabolism. Cytarabine (Option C) is a cytosine arabinoside and pyrimidine analog used in chemotherapy. It is not indicated for gout treatment and does not influence uric acid levels. Febuxostat (Option D) is also a xanthine oxidase inhibitor. While effective for gout, it is not a purine analog. questions.question: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer B- Dermatomyositis The patient's presentation of proximal muscle weakness (difficulty with stairs, rising from chair, and hair combing) along with the pathognomonic violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids (heliotrope rash) suggest Dermatomyositis . This inflammatory myopathy typically affects middle-aged individuals and has a combination of muscle and skin involvement. Dermatomyositis Definition Dermatomyositis is a chronic, inflammatory myositis seen in adults around 50-60 years of age. Clinical features Clinical features It presents as symmetrical muscle weakness (proximal > distal) Gottron’s papules (erythematous scaly papules over knuckles) are pathognomonic of the disease. Scleroderma (Option D) is a connective tissue disorder primarily affecting the skin and internal organs. While it can cause muscle weakness, its hallmark features are skin thickening and fibrosis, not the violaceous rash characteristic of dermatomyositis. It also presents with Raynaud's phenomenon and internal organ involvement.
